quote:
Recently, we reported the construction of a genome-wide biological resource designed to suppress genes required for S. pombe viability (essential genes). PomBase provided the most up-to-date and definitive list of essential genes (1,221 genes). Based on this list, we generated a comprehensive set of conditional knockdown strains. While PomBase enabled us to obtain an updated, data-driven list of essential genes —reflecting the latest findings from recent studies— within only a few hours, manually surveying the literature would require more than 3,700 hours (1221 x 3). Thus, PomBase greatly facilitated our project, which would otherwise have been impossible.

Beyond defining the target set, PomBase also enabled robust functional analyses of our strain libraries. The internal PomBase tool, the Quick Little Tool (QuiLT), was used to classify essential genes according to Gene Ontology biological processes. Although that tool allowed us to obtain a function-based classification of genes within one hour, manually reviewing the literature would again require more than 3,700 hours. This classification enabled us to investigate correlations between a gene’s functional category and its susceptibility to the gene-knockdown method (CRISPRi) utilized in this study. Our analysis revealed that the efficiency of CRISPRi-mediated transcriptional repression varied depending on the functional category of the target gene.

Moreover, PomBase data quantified critical research gaps, thereby justifying the need for the biological resource described in our study. By accessing this genome database, we determined that existing conditional knockdown strains —such as temperature- and cold-sensitive alleles— are available for only 14% of the 1,221 essential genes. Even after incorporating other systematic methods, the total coverage reaches only about 25% (~300 essential genes), leaving roughly 900 essential genes inaccessible to conventional genetic analyses. Although PomBase allowed us to complete this survey within one week, we estimate that performing a manual literature review would require more than 3,700 hours. This clear demonstration of unmet needs, directly supported by PomBase data, served as the impetus for designing and constructing comprehensive libraries capable of perturbing ~98% of all essential genes.

In summary, PomBase is not only an essential data repository that provides foundational genome information; it also offers organizational frameworks (GO/QuiLT) necessary for large-scale genetic projects and identifies limitations in existing biological resources. Its continued curation is indispensable for sustaining long-term efforts to achieve a comprehensive understanding of fundamental biological processes in eukaryotes.

For example, PomBase provides far more efficient access to published studies than PubMed, thanks to its outstanding literature curation. We recently began investigating glycolysis and carbon metabolism, a novel field of research for us. The integration of ontologies, biochemical pathways, and curated article lists significantly accelerated our ability to identify key factors to mutate and important phenotypes to measure.

Another example comes from our recent work on S. pombe strains beyond the type strain. We performed several transcriptomic analyses, and their interpretation relied heavily on the wealth of data available at PomBase, whether via the links to external resources, their integration into a genome browser, or the high-quality ontology annotations. That project simply would not have been possible without PomBase.

Finally, PomBase rapidly integrated the predicted structures from AlphaFold, which allowed us to quickly identify a key difference between two paralogues of the well-studied enzyme invertase. This insight enabled us to design experiments that successfully demonstrated distinct subcellular localization and function.

I consult PomBase daily, and my lab collectively spends many hours each week using the resource. On a personal level, I typically spend several hours per week on PomBase queries, but this time would multiply manyfold if we had to reconstruct the same information from primary literature or disparate databases. PomBase saves us countless hours by integrating curated functional annotations, expression profiles, mutant phenotypes, orthology relationships, and community-generated data into a single, reliable platform.

One compelling example is our 2025 Nucleic Acids Research study (PMID:39878217) on the fission yeast ortholog of human DNAJC9. PomBase was essential for rapidly identifying conserved domains, known interaction partners, and relevant mutant alleles—information that directly shaped our experimental design.

Even more striking is our 2023 G3 paper (PMID:36748990) describing a high-quality reference genome for the related species Schizosaccharomyces osmophilus. That project would have been effectively impossible without PomBase. We depended entirely on PomBase’s rigorously curated S. pombe gene models, gene function annotation, and orthology information to annotate S. osmophilus genes and assign putative functions.

We have cited PomBase in nearly all of our publications. Below are just several examples since 2019:

  • The ortholog of human DNAJC9 promotes histone H3–H4 degradation and is counteracted by Asf1 in fission yeast. Nucleic Acids Res. 2025 (PMID:39878217)
  • A high-quality reference genome for the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces osmophilus. G3. 2023 (PMID:36748990)
  • An improved tetracycline-inducible expression system for fission yeast. J Cell Sci. 2024 (PMID:39318285)
  • Molecular and structural mechanisms of ZZ domain–mediated cargo selection by Nbr1. EMBO J. 2021 (PMID:34169534)
  • Atg1 kinase in fission yeast is activated by Atg11-mediated dimerization and cis-autophosphorylation. eLife 2020 (PMID:32909946)
  • Intraspecific Diversity of Fission Yeast Mitochondrial Genomes. Genome Biol Evol. 2019 (PMID:31364709)
  • Systematic analysis reveals the prevalence and principles of bypassable gene essentiality. Nat Commun. 2019 (PMID:30824696)

quote:
I worked on a project that involved a Quantitative Trait Locus analysis to understand genes responsible for multicellular-like phenotypes in yeast (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.12.15.571870v2).

PomBase was crucial in several ways for this study. For our strongest hit, there was research in other species that linked it to multicellular like phenotypes and PomBase helped us quickly find this research, also linking out to other model organism databases. This also pointed us to data from other researchers who had investigated these genes under different contexts and saved us the time and effort of doing the experiments ourselves so that we could quickly move on to the more important experiments. We may have eventually found that literature ourselves, but by lowering the barrier for finding relevant research, it allows researchers to quickly test hypotheses and make use of one another's work to accelerate science. Without PomBase, fission yeast researchers would be reluctant to branch out to study genes and proteins that they identify in their research that are outside of their specific experience and expertise. With PomBase, researchers can ask the simple questions and find the right papers quickly in a new field, and for the tough questions it helps put them in touch with the experts. There have been an explosion of journals, publications and preprints in recent years and, for the fission yeast community, PomBase does the important role of curating that research so that results get to the right researchers at the right time, and prevents scientists from getting stuck in silos. This is similar to the role that Scientific Conferences play in research, but it is updated in real time (rather than a few times a year), accessible to all (rather than just the small percentage of the community that can go to conferences), is comprehensive and is easily retrievable. PomBase allows fission yeast to be a model organism to a much wider community than it would be if the knowledge were disorganized and specific to just a few labs.
author: Ben Heineike, Post-doctoral researcher, Francis Crick Institute and University College London, UK
